DOC.HEAD: Noriega Forces Surrender Without a Fight in Western Panama
With PM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Members of the Panamanian Defense Forces stacked their guns and raised a white flag in Panama's westernmost city, even though the only sign of U.S. force was two Air Force planes that buzzed the barracks. ``I was just doing my job. I'm not happy about the situation,'' said one police officer, who refused to give his name. The police are part of the Defense Forces that were commanded by ousted dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega. Although Noriega was toppled from power by U.S. forces early Wednesday, he escaped the net thrown by 24,000 U.S. soldiers, sailors and Marines. No U.S. troops showed up in David, despite reports of shooting and fighting in the area, 200 miles west of Panama City and 30 miles east of Costa Rica. On Thursday, two Air Force jets buzzed the Defense Forces barracks in the center of David, witnesses said. On Friday, members of the Defense Forces raised a white banner across the front of the barracks and 100 turned in their weapons, except for sidearms. ``They just stacked their weapons in a pickup truck,'' said Carlos Antonio Rios, a photographer for the Houston Chronicle who had entered Panama from Costa Rica. A small crowd gathered in front of the barracks and waved American flags during the afternoon. Rumors that Noriega himself was in the area were rife during the day, but none could be confirmed. Rumors that he had been captured were scotched by U.S. Army spokesmen. Defense Forces members said they didn't know where Noriega was. Unlike in Panama City, there were only scattered incidents of looting, local residents said, largely because members of the Defense Forces continued to police the streets. At one point, Defense Forces members blocked the entrance to a store and prevented armed men from entering. ``If they want me to work, I'll work,'' said the Defense Forces policeman, when asked if he would work for the newly installed president, Guillermo Endara. ``If they don't, I won't. Whatever they want.''
